title: As we all know friction opposes relative motion, but I never understood why do they say relative not just motion? If I write just motion, why would it be wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: Suppose a man at rest at T=0 , then after two seconds he starts running with an acceleration of 1m/s^2 .  Then from which force this acceleration came into existence.? That's “friction” which provides this acceleration and thus here the “ friction support the motion of the man” , but when you check this motion at contact point of man's foot and ground then-   (You can visualise that when we moves forward, our foot moves in backward direction.) From the above picture you can see that , the velocity of foot with respect to ground (i.e. relative velocity) is in -x direction , so as we know that- “Friction is a force which opposes relative motion or tendency of relative motion” Hence, here to oppose the relative motion ,friction acts in +x direction and provides the acceleration to the man. Remember that, “Friction may or may not opposes the motion but it always opposes relative motion”
When you write motion, you are assuming that one of the surfaces is stationary. Relative motion is a much more generalised term where you don't have to assume anything. It's more scientific also
